explicatoryContent.introduction: Have you ever tried something hard and surprised yourself by doing it? That feeling of 'I can do this!' is called self-efficacy. And have you ever had a really tough day but managed to get through it? That ability to bounce back is called resilience. Both of these are like muscles - the more you use them, the stronger they get. In this topic, we will learn how to build these important skills.
keyPoints: Self-efficacy is believing you can do things.
Resilience is the ability to bounce back from hard times.
Both self-efficacy and resilience can be learned and improved.
Small successes help build bigger confidence.
Having support from others helps build resilience.

analogies.analogy: Self-efficacy is like a battery for your efforts.
analogies.explanation: When your self-efficacy is charged up (you believe you can do something), you have energy to try hard. When it is low (you do not believe you can do it), you might give up easily. The good news is you can recharge your self-efficacy battery through small successes.

analogies.analogy: Resilience is like a rubber ball.
analogies.explanation: When you drop a rubber ball, it bounces back up. Resilience is your ability to bounce back after being knocked down by problems. Some balls bounce higher than others, and you can learn to bounce higher too.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Self-efficacy is about believing in yourself. It is not the same as thinking you are better than others. It is about trusting that you can learn, improve, and handle challenges. When you have high self-efficacy, you are more likely to try new things and keep going when things get hard.

Self-efficacy grows in several ways. First, having success builds confidence. When you do something well, even something small, it shows you that you can do things. Second, seeing others succeed helps too. When you see someone similar to you achieve something, you think 'Maybe I can do that too.' Third, encouragement from others matters. When people you trust say 'You can do this,' it helps you believe it.

Resilience is your ability to cope with hard times. Everyone faces difficulties - problems at home, struggles at school, friendship issues, or bigger challenges. Resilient people still feel upset or stressed, but they find ways to get through it and move forward.

What helps build resilience? Having people who support you is really important. This could be family, friends, teachers, or community members. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities show how connection to family, community, and culture helps people stay strong through challenges.

Other things that help include: having a sense of purpose (knowing what matters to you), being able to solve problems step by step, looking after your physical health, and knowing when to ask for help. Resilience is not about being tough and never asking for help - it is about knowing how to cope and reach out when you need to.

caseStudy.title: Zara Learns to Bounce Back
caseStudy.scenario:
Zara is 15 and recently failed her maths test. She had studied, but still did not do well. At first, Zara felt really bad about herself. She thought 'I am just bad at maths and always will be.'

Zara's older sister noticed she was upset and talked to her. Her sister reminded Zara of the time she learned to ride a bike - she fell off many times but kept trying until she could do it.

Zara realised that failing one test did not mean she was bad at maths forever. She talked to her teacher about what she could do differently. The teacher helped her understand where she went wrong and showed her new ways to study.

For the next test, Zara tried the new study methods. She also reminded herself that she was capable of learning - she had done it before with many things. This time she passed the test.

Zara learned that setbacks do not have to define her. With support and effort, she could bounce back.

explicatoryContent.introduction: How confident do you feel about taking on challenges? How well do you cope when things go wrong? These questions relate to two important personal qualities: self-efficacy and resilience. Self-efficacy is your belief in your ability to succeed at tasks and handle situations. Resilience is your ability to recover from setbacks and keep going. Both of these qualities can be developed and strengthened over time. Understanding how they work can help you build a stronger, more confident you.
keyPoints: Self-efficacy is your belief in your ability to succeed at specific tasks.
Resilience is your capacity to recover from difficulties and adapt to challenges.
Both self-efficacy and resilience are influenced by experiences and can be developed.
Key sources of self-efficacy include past successes, seeing others succeed, encouragement, and managing emotional states.
Protective factors for resilience include supportive relationships, problem-solving skills, and a sense of purpose.

vocabulary.definition: A person's belief in their ability to succeed at a particular task or in a specific situation
The capacity to recover quickly from difficulties and adapt to challenging circumstances
The belief that abilities can be developed through dedication and hard work
The belief that abilities are fixed traits that cannot be significantly changed
Conditions or attributes that help protect people from risks and promote resilience
Methods people use to deal with stressful situations

analogies.analogy: Self-efficacy is like fuel for your actions.
analogies.explanation: Just as a car needs fuel to move, your actions need self-efficacy to get going. When you believe you can do something, you have the fuel to try. When self-efficacy is low, you might not even start the engine. The good news is you can refuel through success experiences and encouragement.

analogies.analogy: Resilience is like a tree in a storm.
analogies.explanation: When strong winds blow, a healthy tree bends but does not break. It has deep roots (supportive relationships), a flexible trunk (coping skills), and can regrow leaves after damage (recover from setbacks). Building resilience is like growing stronger roots and a more flexible trunk.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Self-efficacy, a concept developed by psychologist Albert Bandura, is not the same as general confidence or self-esteem. It is your belief that you can succeed at specific tasks or handle particular situations. You might have high self-efficacy for art but lower self-efficacy for public speaking. Both can be developed.

Bandura identified four main sources of self-efficacy:
1. Mastery experiences - Your past successes. When you have done something well before, you believe you can do it again.
2. Vicarious experiences - Watching others succeed. When you see someone similar to you achieve something, you think 'I could do that too.'
3. Verbal persuasion - Encouragement from others. When people you trust express confidence in you, it helps you believe in yourself.
4. Physiological states - How you feel physically and emotionally. Feeling calm and confident helps; feeling anxious or tired undermines self-efficacy.

Resilience is your ability to cope with adversity and bounce back from difficulties. It is not about never feeling upset or never struggling - resilient people still experience negative emotions. Rather, resilience is about having the resources and skills to recover and adapt.

Protective factors that support resilience include:
- Supportive relationships with family, friends, community, or mentors
- Problem-solving skills and the ability to plan
- Emotional regulation - managing strong feelings
- A sense of purpose or meaning
- Cultural connection and belonging

For Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, connection to family, community, Country, and culture are powerful protective factors. Cultural identity and belonging provide a strong foundation for resilience.

Mindset matters too. People with a growth mindset believe abilities can be developed through effort. This supports resilience because setbacks are seen as opportunities to learn rather than as proof of permanent limitations. People with a fixed mindset believe abilities are fixed, making setbacks more threatening to their self-image.

caseStudy.title: Building Confidence Through Small Steps
caseStudy.scenario:
Jayden is 16 and has always been anxious about public speaking. When his class had to give presentations, he would feel sick and speak too quietly. His self-efficacy for public speaking was very low.

Jayden decided to tackle this challenge step by step. First, he practiced speaking in front of a mirror. Then he read aloud to his family. Next, he answered questions aloud in class (smaller stakes than a full presentation). Finally, he gave a short presentation to a small group of friends who he trusted.

Each small success built his confidence. He also watched videos of young speakers to see that people his age could do it well. His friend Marcus, who was good at presentations, gave him tips and encouragement.

When the next class presentation came, Jayden was still nervous, but he believed he could do it. He had evidence from his smaller successes. He did not become the best presenter overnight, but he got through it and felt proud of his improvement.

He accepted that progress matters more than perfection

For Indigenous students, this includes connecting to culture and community. The key is making these resources available to everyone, especially those who may not have them at home.

explicatoryContent.introduction: Personal empowerment involves developing the confidence, skills, and resources to take control of your life and influence your own outcomes. Two key psychological concepts underpin personal empowerment: self-efficacy (your belief in your ability to succeed at tasks) and resilience (your capacity to adapt and recover from adversity). Research demonstrates that both can be developed through intentional strategies and supportive environments. Understanding the mechanisms behind self-efficacy and resilience enables you to take a more active role in building these crucial qualities.
keyPoints: Self-efficacy is domain-specific - you might have high self-efficacy in some areas and lower in others.
Bandura identified four sources of self-efficacy: mastery experiences, vicarious experiences, verbal persuasion, and physiological/emotional states.
Resilience involves both individual capacities and external resources - it is not purely an individual trait.
Protective factors for resilience include supportive relationships, coping skills, sense of purpose, and cultural connection.
Growth mindset supports both self-efficacy and resilience by framing challenges as opportunities for development.

vocabulary.definition: An individual's belief in their capacity to execute behaviours necessary to produce specific performance outcomes
The process of adapting well in the face of adversity, trauma, tragedy, threats, or significant sources of stress
The process of developing confidence, control, and agency over one's own life and circumstances
Past successes that build confidence in one's abilities
Observing others similar to oneself succeed, which increases belief in one's own capability
Conditions or attributes that reduce the impact of risk factors and promote positive outcomes
Positive psychological change experienced as a result of adversity and struggle

analogies.analogy: Self-efficacy works like a self-fulfilling prophecy.
analogies.explanation: If you believe you can succeed, you are more likely to put in effort, persist through difficulties, and ultimately succeed - which reinforces your belief. If you believe you will fail, you might give up early, leading to failure that confirms your initial belief. Understanding this cycle allows you to intentionally build positive self-efficacy.

analogies.analogy: Resilience is like an immune system for life challenges.
analogies.explanation: Just as your immune system protects against disease using multiple mechanisms (barriers, white blood cells, antibodies), resilience protects against life challenges using multiple resources (relationships, skills, mindset, meaning). You can strengthen this 'immunity' through intentional development.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Self-efficacy, developed as a concept by psychologist Albert Bandura, refers specifically to belief in one's capability to perform actions needed to achieve particular outcomes. It is distinct from self-esteem (general feelings about self-worth) and from actual ability. Self-efficacy influences whether you attempt challenging tasks, how much effort you invest, how long you persist when facing difficulties, and how you recover from setbacks.

Self-efficacy is domain-specific rather than general. You might have high self-efficacy for mathematical problem-solving but lower self-efficacy for creative writing. Both can be developed through intentional strategies targeting the four sources Bandura identified:

1. Mastery experiences: The most powerful source. Success builds confidence; failure undermines it (especially if failure occurs before self-efficacy is established). The key is creating opportunities for success, starting with achievable challenges and gradually increasing difficulty.

2. Vicarious experiences: Seeing people similar to yourself succeed increases belief that you can do the same. This is why role models and mentors are valuable - and why representation matters.

3. Verbal persuasion: Encouragement from credible sources can boost self-efficacy, particularly when it is specific and realistic. Generic praise is less effective than specific feedback that recognises genuine effort and improvement.

4. Physiological and emotional states: Stress, anxiety, and fatigue can undermine performance and self-efficacy. Learning to interpret physiological arousal as preparation rather than threat can help.

Resilience research has shifted from viewing resilience as an innate individual trait to understanding it as a dynamic process influenced by both individual capacities and environmental resources. Current models emphasise that resilience emerges from the interaction between individuals and their social ecologies.

Protective factors at multiple levels support resilience:
- Individual: problem-solving skills, emotional regulation, sense of purpose, growth mindset
- Relational: supportive family, positive peer relationships, mentors
- Community: belonging to cultural groups, access to resources, safe environments

For Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, cultural connection, connection to Country, and community belonging are powerful protective factors. Research consistently shows that strong cultural identity supports resilience for Indigenous young people.

Post-traumatic growth is a related concept describing positive psychological changes that can result from struggling with highly challenging circumstances. While adversity causes distress, some people also report increased appreciation for life, improved relationships, greater personal strength, recognition of new possibilities, and spiritual development. This does not mean adversity is good, but it suggests that humans have capacity for growth through struggle.

caseStudy.title: Emily's Resilience Journey
caseStudy.scenario:
Emily is 17 and was diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes at age 14. The diagnosis was devastating - she had to completely change how she ate, constantly monitor her blood sugar, and inject insulin multiple times daily. She went through a period of denial and depression.

Over time, Emily developed resilience around managing her condition. Several factors contributed:

Supportive relationships: Her family learned about diabetes with her. Her diabetes educator was a young woman who also had Type 1 and became a mentor.

Mastery experiences: Each successful day of management built confidence. She learned to recognise how different foods and activities affected her blood sugar.

Sense of purpose: Emily started a blog sharing her experiences, which helped other young people with diabetes. This gave meaning to her struggle.

Growth mindset: She reframed the diagnosis from 'This ruins my life' to 'This is a challenge I can learn to manage.'

Emily now speaks at diabetes events and mentors newly diagnosed teenagers. She describes experiencing post-traumatic growth - while she would not have chosen to have diabetes, the experience has given her strengths and perspectives she values.

This does not mean Emily never struggles. Some days are hard, and she still experiences frustration. Resilience is not about never having difficult feelings but about having resources to cope and recover.

Multiple protective factors contributed to her resilience
She experienced both genuine distress and eventual growth
Resilience involved resources beyond just individual traits

caseStudy.realWorldConnection: Many people face significant health challenges, family difficulties, or other adversities. Understanding the factors that support resilience can help individuals, families, and communities create conditions for coping and growth.

relational.stem: Explain the relationship between growth mindset and resilience. How does mindset affect how people respond to adversity?
relational.modelResponse: Growth mindset and resilience are closely connected. When people believe abilities can be developed through effort (growth mindset), they interpret setbacks as opportunities to learn rather than evidence of permanent limitations. This makes them more likely to persist through difficulties, seek help, and try new strategies - all of which support resilience. In contrast, fixed mindset can undermine resilience by making setbacks feel like proof of inadequacy, leading to giving up. Growth mindset supports the cognitive reframing that helps people adapt to and grow from adversity.
relational.rubric: Shows clear understanding of the relationship

extendedAbstract.stem: How might understanding self-efficacy and resilience as developmental processes (rather than fixed traits) change how schools, families, and communities support young people?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Understanding self-efficacy and resilience as developmental would shift focus from identifying who 'has' these qualities to creating conditions that develop them in all young people. Schools could intentionally design mastery experiences, provide diverse role models, train staff in effective encouragement, and teach stress management. Families could focus on process rather than outcome, provide appropriate challenge, and maintain supportive connections. Communities could ensure all young people have access to mentors, cultural connection, and opportunities for meaningful contribution. This approach would address equity - rather than resilience being an advantage some children arrive with, it becomes something all environments aim to build. It would also reduce stigma around struggling, recognising that developing these qualities takes time and support.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Extends to systemic implications with sophisticated reasoning

explicatoryContent.introduction: Self-efficacy and resilience are not merely individual psychological attributes but emerge from the dynamic interaction between persons and their social-ecological contexts. Albert Bandura's social cognitive theory positions self-efficacy as central to human agency, operating through motivational, cognitive, affective, and decisional mechanisms. Contemporary resilience research, drawing on ecological systems theory, emphasises that resilience is not an individual trait but a process involving the navigation of resources across multiple levels of the social ecology. Understanding these frameworks provides sophisticated tools for analysing personal development and for designing effective interventions.
keyPoints: Self-efficacy operates through multiple mechanisms: cognitive (expectations, attributions), motivational (effort, persistence), affective (emotional reactions), and selection (choice of activities and environments).
Reciprocal determinism describes how personal factors, behaviours, and environments interact in shaping development.
Ecological resilience models emphasise resources at multiple levels (individual, family, community, culture, society) and the processes of navigating these resources.
Structural factors (socioeconomic conditions, discrimination, access to opportunities) significantly influence the development and distribution of self-efficacy and resilience.
Effective interventions address multiple levels and recognise that individual empowerment requires supportive environments.

The dynamic interaction between personal factors, behaviour, and environment, each influencing the others

analogies.analogy: Reciprocal determinism is like a conversation between you and your world.
analogies.explanation: In a conversation, what you say affects what others say, which affects what you think and say next. Similarly, your thoughts, behaviours, and environment are in constant dialogue. Your beliefs influence your actions; your actions change your environment; and your changed environment influences your beliefs. This ongoing interaction shapes development.

analogies.analogy: Ecological resilience is like the health of a coral reef.
analogies.explanation: A coral reef's resilience depends not just on individual corals but on the whole ecosystem - water quality, fish populations, temperature, and many interacting factors. Similarly, human resilience depends not just on individual characteristics but on the whole social ecology - family, community, culture, and structural conditions. You cannot assess or build resilience by focusing only on the individual.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Bandura's social cognitive theory provides a sophisticated framework for understanding human agency. Central to this framework is the concept of reciprocal determinism - the dynamic interplay between personal factors (beliefs, expectations, emotions), behavioural patterns, and environmental influences. Rather than behaviour being determined either by internal dispositions or external circumstances, Bandura argues that all three components interact to shape human functioning.

Self-efficacy operates through several mechanisms:
- Cognitive processes: Self-efficacy influences goal-setting, problem analysis, and causal attributions. High self-efficacy leads to setting challenging goals and interpreting setbacks as solvable problems rather than evidence of inadequacy.
- Motivational processes: Self-efficacy affects effort and persistence. People with high self-efficacy invest more effort and persist longer in the face of difficulties.
- Affective processes: Self-efficacy influences emotional reactions to challenge. High self-efficacy reduces anxiety and enables approach rather than avoidance.
- Selection processes: Self-efficacy affects the activities and environments people choose, shaping their developmental trajectory.

Bandura also developed the concept of collective efficacy - a group's belief in its combined capabilities. This is relevant to understanding how communities and organisations function.

Contemporary resilience research has moved from individual trait models toward ecological perspectives. Michael Ungar's work, for example, emphasises that resilience is not a personal attribute but a process involving both the capacity of individuals to navigate toward resources and the capacity of their social ecologies to provide resources in culturally meaningful ways. This shifts attention from individual coping to the availability and accessibility of resources.

For Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, resilience is deeply connected to cultural continuity, connection to Country, and community strength. Research highlights the importance of cultural identity and self-determination as resilience resources, and the ongoing impacts of colonisation as structural barriers.

Structural analysis reveals how self-efficacy and resilience are unequally distributed. Factors such as socioeconomic status, discrimination, and access to educational opportunities shape the development of self-efficacy. Those with more resources have more opportunities for mastery experiences, access to role models, and supportive environments. This means that 'building resilience' cannot be purely an individual project but requires addressing structural inequalities.

Effective interventions therefore operate at multiple levels - building individual capacities while also strengthening families, communities, and addressing structural barriers. Interventions focused only on individual skills without addressing context often have limited impact.

caseStudy.title: Analysing Community-Based Resilience Building
caseStudy.scenario:
Consider the Clontarf Foundation, an Australian organisation that supports young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander men through sport-based academies in schools. The program does not focus on individual resilience training but creates an ecological system of support.

Key elements include:
- Mentoring relationships with Aboriginal men who model success and provide ongoing support
- Connection to cultural identity and pride in Aboriginality
- Skill development including academic, vocational, and life skills
- A supportive peer community with positive norms
- Physical activity and structured routine
- Links to employment and further education pathways

The program addresses multiple levels of the social ecology: individual (skills, identity), relational (mentors, peers), community (school integration, cultural connection), and structural (pathways to employment, addressing some barriers to opportunity).

Outcome data shows participants have significantly higher school attendance and completion rates than non-participants. The program illustrates ecological resilience principles - it works not by teaching individuals to be resilient but by creating resource-rich environments that support positive development.

This contrasts with purely individual approaches that might teach coping skills without addressing the social and structural factors that create adversity and limit opportunities.

relational.stem: Explain how reciprocal determinism helps us understand why interventions that only target individual beliefs often have limited lasting impact.
relational.modelResponse: Reciprocal determinism shows that personal beliefs, behaviours, and environments are in constant interaction. If you change only individual beliefs without changing the environment or building new behaviours, the environment will likely reinforce old patterns. For example, building a student's self-efficacy through motivation training but returning them to a non-supportive classroom creates contradiction - the environment undermines the changed beliefs. Lasting change requires addressing all three components, which is why multi-level interventions are more effective.

extendedAbstract.stem: How might Indigenous models of resilience, which emphasise cultural connection and collective wellbeing, inform and improve mainstream approaches to resilience intervention?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Indigenous resilience models could transform mainstream approaches in several ways. First, they emphasise collective and relational dimensions often missing from individualistic Western frameworks - resilience is understood as community strength, not just personal coping. Second, they highlight cultural connection as a resilience resource, suggesting interventions should support cultural identity rather than impose dominant cultural norms. Third, they prioritise self-determination - community control over defining and addressing wellbeing needs. This challenges interventions designed and delivered by outsiders. Fourth, they recognise ongoing impacts of colonisation as structural factors affecting resilience, requiring attention to justice and systemic change alongside individual support. Integrating these insights would make mainstream approaches more holistic, culturally responsive, and attentive to structural factors.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Synthesises Indigenous perspectives with mainstream approaches with sophisticated analysis

explicatoryContent.introduction: Self-efficacy and resilience have become dominant concepts in psychology, education, and public health. Yet these concepts are not ideologically neutral. Critical scholars argue that resilience discourse can function to shift responsibility from structural conditions to individuals, effectively asking people to adapt to adversity rather than challenging the conditions that create it. This does not mean these concepts are useless - but it requires holding them with critical awareness of their assumptions and limitations. Alternative frameworks, including Indigenous knowledge systems, offer different ways of understanding human flourishing that may avoid some of the pitfalls of individualistic Western psychology.
keyPoints: Self-efficacy theory rests on assumptions about individual agency that may not translate across all cultural contexts.
Resilience discourse has political dimensions - it can function to responsibilise individuals for structural problems.
Critical analysis asks: 'resilience to what?' and 'whose interests does resilience discourse serve?'
Indigenous frameworks offer relational and collective understandings of wellbeing that challenge Western individualism.
Effective empowerment requires both individual capacity-building and structural transformation.

A political-economic ideology emphasising free markets, individual responsibility, and minimal state intervention
Adjusting desires and expectations downward in response to limited options, potentially masking injustice
Harm caused by social structures and institutions that prevent people from meeting their basic needs
Fairness in how knowledge is produced, validated, and shared, particularly regarding marginalised groups
The pursuit of freedom from oppression through collective action and structural transformation

analogies.analogy: Critical analysis of resilience is like asking why we expect people to swim rather than questioning why they are being thrown into the water.
analogies.explanation: Resilience interventions often focus on building people's capacity to cope with adversity (swimming skills) without questioning the structures that create adversity (who is throwing whom into the water, and why). A complete analysis must address both individual coping capacities and the structural conditions that create the need for coping.

analogies.analogy: The relationship between individual and structural change is like dealing with both symptoms and causes of illness.
analogies.explanation: Treating symptoms provides immediate relief but does not address underlying causes. Addressing only causes might leave people suffering while awaiting systemic change. Similarly, individual empowerment can provide immediate benefit while structural transformation addresses root causes. Neither alone is sufficient; both are needed in appropriate relationship.

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Self-efficacy and resilience concepts emerged from particular cultural and historical contexts and carry assumptions that deserve scrutiny. Bandura's self-efficacy theory, while immensely influential, rests on an agentic model of selfhood emphasising individual control and self-direction. This model may not adequately capture human functioning in contexts where interdependence, collective identity, and contextual factors are emphasised.

Critical scholarship has raised concerns about how resilience discourse functions politically, particularly under neoliberal governance. These critiques include:

1. Responsibilisation: Resilience discourse can shift responsibility from structural conditions to individuals. If people are expected to be resilient, the focus becomes their adaptation rather than addressing conditions that create adversity. This is particularly concerning when applied to marginalised groups facing systemic discrimination.

2. Depoliticisation: By framing adversity as a context for individual growth, resilience discourse can depoliticise problems that require collective and structural responses. Poverty, racism, and environmental degradation become matters for individual coping rather than political contestation.

3. The question 'resilience to what?': Not all adversity should be adapted to. Some conditions demand transformation, not adaptation. Developing resilience to unjust conditions could constitute what philosophers call adaptive preference - adjusting expectations to limited options in ways that mask injustice.

4. Whose interests?: Critical analysis asks who benefits from resilience discourse. If disadvantaged groups are taught to be resilient while structural privileges remain unchallenged, resilience serves to maintain rather than transform unequal relations.

These critiques do not mean self-efficacy and resilience are meaningless concepts - people do need capacities to cope with difficulties they face. But they suggest the need for structural analysis alongside individual intervention.

Indigenous knowledge systems offer alternative frameworks. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander scholars articulate understandings of wellbeing grounded in relational ontologies, where flourishing is fundamentally collective and connected to Country and culture. These frameworks challenge Western assumptions about individual agency while providing resources for understanding collective resilience, self-determination, and healing from collective trauma.

A synthesis might recognise that:
- Individual capacity-building has value but cannot substitute for structural change
- Structural change without individual empowerment can leave people without resources to navigate during transition
- Both must be pursued together, with clarity about their relationship
- Different knowledge systems offer different insights, and epistemic justice requires taking multiple frameworks seriously

caseStudy.title: Critical Analysis of Youth Resilience Policy
caseStudy.scenario:
Consider how 'building youth resilience' has become a prominent policy goal in Australian education and welfare. Programs aim to equip young people with coping skills to deal with challenges including mental health difficulties, academic pressure, family problems, and online risks.

A critical analysis might ask:

1. What adversities are young people being asked to be resilient to? Many relate to structural factors: educational systems that create excessive pressure, housing insecurity, family stress from economic conditions, social media platforms designed to maximise engagement regardless of harm, and for some, discrimination based on identity.

2. Who benefits from the focus on individual resilience? Such programs may benefit governments seeking to address youth distress without structural investment; schools seeking to improve student outcomes without changing demanding practices; and platforms seeking to avoid regulation while appearing to care about youth wellbeing.

3. What is not addressed? Resilience programs rarely advocate for structural changes: mental health funding, educational reform, housing policy, technology regulation, or addressing discrimination. The focus on individual skills assumes the individual is the appropriate site of intervention.

4. Are there adaptive preferences at play? Young people might internalise that their role is to cope with whatever they face, limiting their vision of what might be changed collectively.

This does not mean resilience programs are worthless - young people do face challenges and benefit from coping skills. But a complete response would address both individual capacities and structural conditions, supporting young people's collective voice and agency rather than just individual adaptation.

Structural factors creating adversity often remain unaddressed
There are questions about whose interests resilience discourse serves
A complete response requires both individual and structural elements

multistructural.stem: List THREE critiques that critical scholars make of resilience discourse.
multistructural.modelResponse: Three critiques are: (1) Responsibilisation - shifting responsibility from structures to individuals; (2) Depoliticisation - framing structural problems as individual matters; (3) Whose interests? - questioning who benefits from the focus on individual adaptation rather than structural change.

relational.stem: Explain the relationship between individual empowerment and structural transformation. Why are both needed, and what happens if only one is pursued?
relational.modelResponse: Individual empowerment and structural transformation are complementary but address different levels of the problem. Individual empowerment builds capacities people need to navigate current conditions and participate in change, but if pursued alone, it can leave structures unchallenged, effectively asking people to adapt to injustice. Structural transformation addresses root causes, but if pursued without individual empowerment, people may lack resources during transition or capacity to participate in change. The relationship should be both/and: building individual capacities while working for structural change, with clarity that individual coping is not a substitute for addressing structural causes.
relational.rubric: Shows clear understanding of the relationship and why both are needed

extendedAbstract.stem: How might Indigenous concepts of collective wellbeing, connection to Country, and relational ontology transform not only how we understand resilience, but also how we approach intervention, policy, and the relationship between individuals and communities?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Indigenous concepts would transform our approach at multiple levels. Ontologically, relational understanding would shift focus from building individual capacities to strengthening relationships, connections, and collective resources. Resilience would be understood as community strength, cultural continuity, and connection to Country rather than individual coping. Epistemologically, this would require privileging Indigenous knowledge and self-determination - communities defining their own wellbeing and solutions rather than having external frameworks imposed. Practically, interventions would focus on collective resources, cultural revitalisation, and self-determination rather than individual skill-building. Policy would prioritise Indigenous control over services, land rights, and cultural preservation as resilience resources. The relationship between individuals and communities would be understood as fundamentally constitutive - wellbeing is not individual but relational. This challenges the individualism underlying Western psychology and opens possibilities for approaches that are collective, culturally grounded, and transformative rather than adaptive.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Synthesises Indigenous perspectives with sophisticated analysis of implications
